titleInfo.title: Fragment of a Glossarium
Philip Bliss Collection
titleInfo.subTitle: Medieval manuscript fragments, ca. 850-1499

originInfo.dateCreated: early in the second half of the 9th c.

physicalDescription.note: Partial parchment bifolium, arranged in three columns per page. Ruled in dry point. Pricking on outer column of each leaf. Folds and excisions indicate later use in a binding.

mods.abstract: Carolingian glossary of Latin words with their variant definitions and uses. Likely from either the Glossarium Ansileubi or Librum Glossarum. Arrangement is alphabetical. Sources cited in the margins make references to classical authors, including Cicero, Virgil, and Isidore. Contents of this description initially drawn from bookseller's description and augmentedy by undergraduate and graduate student research done in Stanford paleography and codicology courses from the 1970s-present. Student transcriptions and research papers are available upon request.
mods.note: Early Carolingian miniscule.

titleInfo.title: Reported to: Bibliotheque Nationale pre-1600 manuscript census.
Fragment of a Carolingian compilation on the Psalms
Philip Bliss Collection
titleInfo.subTitle: Medieval manuscript fragments, ca. 850-1499

place.placeTerm: France, probably north of the Loire

physicalDescription.note: 1 leaf: 330 mm x 262 mm. Writing box: 260mm x 204mm. Two columns of 34 lines each, columns 15mm apart. Ruling with a hard point, four single vertical bounding lines in center column, double vertical bounding lines on margin. Prickings clearly visible 14 mm from outer edge.

mods.abstract: This leaf is one of two Stanford-owned leaves originating from the same dispersed book. The texts on the two leaves appear to have been compiled as prefatory matter, either before a commentary or preceding a Psalter. They include a hitherto unrecorded commentary on the Psalms, apparently of Carolingian authorship, and an early appearance of a prologue attributed to Bede, or pesudo-Bede. This leaf contains 4 sequential texts. Text 1 begins (mid-word) "-brius succidatur. Unde consueta" and ends "de purissimo fonte potare" : identified as part of Jerome's preface to the 'Hebrew Psalter,' Patrologia Latina 29, cols 118-120. Text 2 begins "Dum multa corpora liborum" and ends "per bonefacium presbiterum heirosolima": identified as Letter 5 of Pseudo-Damasus to Jerome, Patrologia Latina 13, col. 440. Text 3 begins "Beatissimo pape damaso sedix apostolicae hieronomus simplex. Legi litteras" and ends (on verso) "laudis semper canatur": identified as Ep. XLVII, Letter of Pseudo-Jerome to Pope Damasus, Patrologia Latina, 30 cols. 294-5. Text 4 begins on the first leaf with "David filius iesse cum esset in regno suo." The text is from a commentary on the pslams and continues on the second leaf but the text is non-continuous." See also M0389. Box 1, Folder 02, Item 2. Contents of this abstract drawn from accompanying dealer's notes and related correspondance.
mods.note: The script is a slightly sloping caroline minuscule, with uncial headings for the letters and a rustic captial heading for the prologue. Abbreviations are limited and standard. Corrections are generally neat interlinear insertions with the word to be corrected indicated by a line of dots placed under it.

titleInfo.title: Reported to: Bibliotheque Nationale pre-1600 manuscript census.
Fragment of a Carolingian compilation on the Psalms
Philip Bliss Collection
titleInfo.subTitle: Medieval manuscript fragments, ca. 850-1499

place.placeTerm: France, probably north of the Loire

physicalDescription.note: 1 leaf: originally 330 mm x 262 mm. Writing box: 260 mm x 204 mm. This leaf has been cut down irregularly to approximately 180 mm wide. Two columns of 34 lines each, columns 15mm apart. Ruling with a hard point, four single vertical bounding lines in center column, double vertical bounding lines on margin. Prickings clearly visible 14 mm from outer edge.

mods.abstract: This leaf is one of two Stanford-owned leaves originating from the same dispersed book. The texts on the two leaves appear to have been compiled as prefatory matter, either before a commentary or preceding a Psalter. They include a hitherto unrecorded commentary on the Psalms, apparently of Carolingian authorship, and an early appearance of a prologue attributed to Bede, or pesudo-Bede. This leaf contains part of a commentary on the psalms, which begins as text 4 on the first in this folder. The text begins "delectatio terrore iuxta conpugeretur" and ends "Quid utique inpossible est ut quis." This commentary is included in Bede's Dubia et Spuria, Patrologia Latina 93, cols. 477-80. It was See also M0389. Box 1, Folder 02, Item 1. Contents of this abstract drawn from accompanying dealer's notes and related correspondance.
mods.note: The script is a slightly sloping caroline minuscule, with uncial headings for the letters and a rustic captial heading for the prologue. Abbreviations are limited and standard. Corrections are generally neat interlinear insertions with the word to be corrected indicated by a line of dots placed under it.

titleInfo.title: Reported to: Bibliotheque Nationale pre-1600 manuscript census.
Fragment from a monastic diurnal antiphonary
Philip Bliss Collection
titleInfo.subTitle: Medieval manuscript fragments, ca. 850-1499

originInfo.dateCreated: second half of the 10th or first half of the 11th c.

physicalDescription.note: 1 bifolium leaf of parchment measuring 300 mm x 215 mm. Text is written in a single column of 24 written lines. Ruling is with dry point done on the hair side.First line of text written above the top ruling line. No prickings are visible. Membrane is quite thin in places, some holes

mods.abstract: Contains chants and readings for the celebration of the day hours of the Office, starting with the end of Dec 27 through the middle of December 28th (Offices for the Holy Innocents). Possibly from a collectar. The second folio contains chant and readings for December 30 and December 31 (feast of St. Silvester). Antiphons, short responsories, and a single hymn are present. Music was added after the words. The notation is a Germanic variant of the unheighted St. Gall neumatic system. Contents of this description drawn from student research done in Stanford paleography and codicology courses. Student transcriptions and research papers are available upon request.
mods.note: Continental caroline minuscule of two sizes. Litterae notabiliores are in uncial.
Orange decorative initials begin each prayer or scripture reading. Rubrics of the same color indicate the beginning of each hour of the Office.

titleInfo.title: Reported to: Bibliotheque Nationale pre-1600 manuscript census.
Fragment of Liturgy, Ottonian sacramentary
Philip Bliss Collection
titleInfo.subTitle: Medieval manuscript fragments, ca. 850-1499

physicalDescription.note: Bifolium comprising one complete leaf and most of the second.

mods.abstract: Bifolium comprising one complete leaf and most of the second. Temporal, readings for Quadragesima Sunday. Missal, Votive Masses for Priest(s).
mods.note: Late Carolingian minuscule.

titleInfo.title: Reported to: Bibliotheque Nationale pre-1600 manuscript census.
Fragment from a Beneventan Psalter
Philip Bliss Collection
titleInfo.subTitle: Medieval manuscript fragments, ca. 850-1499

physicalDescription.note: Bifolium of parchment measuring 295 mm x 210 mm. Single column of 18 lines. Ruling in dry point on the hair side. Double bounding lines for each column. Cut down from original size for use in a later binding. Hair follicles vixible. Margins and one line of text have been lost as a result of trimming, as well as any prickings or quire marks. Walter damage and plentiful wormholes apparent along left side of the recto. Fragment likely used as endleaf in a later book.

mods.abstract: Fragment from a Beneventan psalter, containing most of Psalm 36: verses 1-29. For an early printed edition of this text in its relation to other versions of the psalter, see Jacques Lefevre d'Etaples's Quincuplex Psalterium, 1513. Contents of this description drawn from student research done in Stanford paleography and codicology courses. Student transcriptions and research papers are available upon request.
mods.note: Large Beneventan script. Initials show elements of uncial and rustic captial letter forms.
Psalm begins with an initial drawn in pen with interlaced design, partially colored in red and yellow. Versals are set in the left margin and written in red, filled with yellow.

titleInfo.title: Reported to: Bibliotheque Nationale pre-1600 manuscript census.
Fragment from St. Augustine's" Tractus in Iohannem"
Philip Bliss Collection
titleInfo.subTitle: Medieval manuscript fragments, ca. 850-1499

originInfo.dateCreated: first half of the 12th c. Possibly c. 1130

physicalDescription.note: Single parchment leaf measuring 42.5 cm x 30 cm. Two columns of 44 lines each. Ruling in dry point. Prickings appear in right margin of recto.

mods.abstract: Fragment of St. Augustine's "Tractatus in Johannem," including tracts 49.27 to 50.6 in the modern numbering. This manuscript numbers the same tracts as the end of tract 50 through beginning of 51. See Corpus Christianorum Series Latina XXXVI, pp. 432-35. Contents of this description drawn from student research done in Stanford paleography and codicology courses. Student transcriptions and research papers are available upon request.
mods.note: Roman minuscule (derived from Carolingian minuscule) of two sizes. Moderate amount of standard abbreviation.

White-vine 'H' in red, yellow, green, brown, and blue at the beginning of tract 51. This style of full-shafted initials is peculiar to central Italy, and was standard, especially with use of red and and yellow fillets, in the second quarter of the twelfth century. 3.4cm red 'I' in column b on verso, marking a division of the text.

titleInfo.title: Reported to: Bibliotheque Nationale pre-1600 manuscript census.
Fragment of a Grammar of the Latin language
Philip Bliss Collection
titleInfo.subTitle: Medieval manuscript fragments, ca. 850-1499

mods.abstract: Bifolium. One of two Stanford-owned bifolia originating from the same dispersed book. Contains discussion of grammatical phenomena including inchoative verbs, supines, and gerundives. Forms of amo are especially represented, but other verbs too are discussed. See also, M0389. Box 1, Folder 07, Item 2.
mods.note: Late Carolingian hand.

titleInfo.title: Reported to: Bibliotheque Nationale pre-1600 manuscript census.

titleInfo.subTitle: Medieval manuscript fragments, ca. 850-1499

mods.abstract: Bifolium. One of two Stanford-owned bifolia originating from the same dispersed book. Contains discussion of grammatical phenomena including inchoative verbs, supines, and gerundives. Forms of amo are especially represented, but other verbs too are discussed. See also, M0389. Box 1, Folder 07, Item 1.

titleInfo.subTitle: Medieval manuscript fragments, ca. 850-1499

mods.abstract: Leaf. From the Office of Matins for the feast of the Conversion of St. Paul (25 January).
mods.note: Late Carolingian hand.

Fragment from a Bible
Philip Bliss Collection
titleInfo.subTitle: Medieval manuscript fragments, ca. 850-1499

physicalDescription.note: Bible text is written in a single column of 27 lines with two columns of marginal and interlinear gloss.

mods.abstract: Isaiah, ch. 33, 23-35. One chapter has commentary from the Glossa Ordinaria. Bible text is written in a single column of 27 lines with two columns of marginal and interlinear gloss.
mods.note: Angular gothic hand in three sizes.

titleInfo.title: Reported to: Bibliotheque Nationale pre-1600 manuscript census.
Fragment of Church music, secular breviary
Philip Bliss Collection
titleInfo.subTitle: Medieval manuscript fragments, ca. 850-1499

physicalDescription.note: 1 parchment folio measuring 24.3 cm x 17 cm. Text is written in two columns. Any pricking has been lost by trimming. A thin strip of modern material runs along the inner edge of the verso.

mods.abstract: Fragment from a secular breviary marking the feast day of St. John the Evangelist (December 27) with office text and noted music. Music notation on 4-line staves. Contents of this description drawn from student research done in Stanford paleography and codicology courses. Student transcriptions and research papers are available upon request.
mods.note: Small Gothic script with frequent abbreviations

titleInfo.title: Reported to: Bibliotheque Nationale pre-1600 manuscript census.
Fragment from Latin translation of Aristotle's Physical with commentary by Averroes
Philip Bliss Collection
titleInfo.subTitle: Medieval manuscript fragments, ca. 850-1499

mods.abstract: Leaf. One of two Stanford-owned leaves originating from the same dispersed book. Contains Aristotle's work in Latin translation accompanied by commentary by Averroes. Fol. 1 includes text of Physics 1.5 with commentary. Likely from a scholastic textbook. See also, M0389. Box 1, Folder 11, Item 2. Contents of this description drawn from student research done in Stanford paleography and codicology courses. Student transcriptions and research papers are available upon request.
mods.note: Gothic bookhand. Side-notes in a cursive 14th-c. hand.

titleInfo.title: Reported to: Bibliotheque Nationale pre-1600 manuscript census.
Fragment from Latin translation of Aristotle's Physical with commentary by Averroes
Philip Bliss Collection
titleInfo.subTitle: Medieval manuscript fragments, ca. 850-1499

mods.abstract: Leaf. One of two Stanford-owned leaves originating from the same dispersed book. Contains Aristotle's work in Latin translation with commentary by Averroes. Fol. 2 includes text of Physics 2.1 with commentary. Likely from a scholastic textbook. See also, M0389. Box 1, Folder 11, Item 1. Contents of this abstract enriched by student research done in Stanford paleography and codicology courses. Student transcriptions available upon request.
mods.note: Gothic bookhand. Side-notes in a cursive 14th-c. hand.

titleInfo.title: Reported to: Bibliotheque Nationale pre-1600 manuscript census.
Venetian Guild of Rag Merchants Inventory
Philip Bliss Collection
titleInfo.subTitle: Medieval manuscript fragments, ca. 850-1499

physicalDescription.note: Single leaf on parchment. Fold marks and excisions indicate this leaf's use in bookbinding.

mods.abstract: Leaf containing what appears to be an inventory of the Venetian Guild of Rag Merchants. Contents of this description drawn from student research done in Stanford paleography and codicology courses. Student transcriptions and research papers are available upon request.
mods.note: Square Italian bookhand.

titleInfo.title: Reported to: Bibliotheque Nationale pre-1600 manuscript census.
Fragment from Guillaume de Peraldo, "Tractus de professione monachorum"
Philip Bliss Collection
titleInfo.subTitle: Medieval manuscript fragments, ca. 850-1499

physicalDescription.note: 1 non-consecutive bifolium of parchment. Fol. 1 measures 19.5 mm x 15.3 mm. Fol. 2 measures 19.3 mm x 14.7 mm -- MM?! REALLY?! 1 Column of 31 lines. Ruling in plummet. Seven sewing holes along center fold.

mods.abstract: Fragment from Tractatus de Professione Monachorum, by Guillaume de Peraldo (or Perault), a manual on the proper behavior of monks, using classical and biblical references to demonstrate proper conduct. Contents of this description drawn from student research done in Stanford paleography and codicology courses. Student transcriptions and research papers are available upon request.
mods.note: Gothic bookhand. Numerous manicula throughout both folios and a few marginal annotations.
Rubrication of some captials and the first letter of new paragraphs. 10-line rubricated 'S' on fol. 1r.

mods.abstract: Partial leaf. Contains elegiac verses about nature and the fates.
mods.note: Secretary hand.

mods.abstract: Leaf. Text includes an account of an adulterer named Aldhelm, who lived in Leicestershire about 1450.
mods.note: Secretary hand.
